column4:
Introduction

About this course
Behavioural scientists are interested in all aspects of our lives and behaviour. They ask questions about how people behave and about the society they live in. They want to understand the effects our culture and society has on us and the effects we have on our culture and society. They try to find answers to the practical everyday problems we all encounter.

In our Behavioural Science course you will learn about how people think, act and interact in society. You will learn scientific methods of investigating, analysing and interpreting behaviour. In the first two years, you will study the foundations of psychology and sociology, as well as relevant aspects of IT and research methods. In third and fourth year, you will be able to study sociological topics such as the sociology of health and illness, crime and deviance, gender studies, social movements, Scottish culture and society, as well as psychology topics such as health psychology, sport psychology, language development, abnormal psychology and clinical psychology. On completion of this course, you will possess a sound understanding of research methods, and will be able to draw upon a wide range of social and psychological knowledge to apply to practical, every day problems and use as a basis for employment or further study.

At the end of year two, if you decide you would like to specialise in sociology or in psychology you may do so and will go on to graduate with BSc (Hons) Sociology or BSc (Hons) Psychology (see the Sociology and Psychology course entries for details).

Core Themes

What you study
Stage 1
Introductory psychology; individual in society; research methods in psychology; globalisation and society; history and social change, reading sociology.
Stage 2
Research methods (Psychology and Sociology); biological psychology; classical social theory; self & society; cognitive psychology; work welfare & consumption.
Stage 3
Development & intelligence; research methods; contemporary sociological theories; understanding collective behaviour; personality and social psychology plus options from sociology of gender, sociological methods, cultural theory, crime & punishment, Scottish culture, sociology of leisure and tourism, applied psychology, abnormal behaviour, psychology and the law, social influence, behaviour & health, biological & cognitive psychology, sport psychology and more.
Stage 4
Psychology or sociology project (on a topic of your choice); plus options from the following subject areas: science and society, penal institutions, media, self and society, cultural theory, images of the city, the social organisation of sexuality, conversation analysis, political sociology, visualising the environment, psychology of language, psychology of education and health, biological psychology, cognitive psychology, psychopharmacology, clinical psychology, forensic psychology and more.

How you learn
You will learn in a variety of different ways that reflect the diverse knowledge and skills required for a Behavioural Science graduate. Class contact time will be on average 8 hours per week made up of lectures, seminars and laboratories. You will be expected to attend lectures that will offer an overview of the main topics and provide directions to guide your independent reading. You will also participate in laboratory classes that will help to develop your practical and experimental skills; and in seminars that give you the opportunity to participate in discussions groups and to develop your communication skills and private study.

How you are assessed
A variety of assessment methods are used throughout the course including formal examinations using seen and unseen papers, class tests, essays, laboratory reports, poster presentations and formal oral presentations. All Behavioural Science degree students will either undertake a psychology or sociology research project in their fourth year culminating in a 10,000 word dissertation on a topic chosen by the student.

Career Opportunities:

There are a wide variety of opportunities for you once you have completed your behavioural science degree. Behavioural science graduates are well suited to âpeople-orientedâ occupations such as management, personnel, public relations, marketing, community education, youth work, social research, the police or the criminal justice service, drug rehabilitation, and many more. Many of our students go on to complete professional qualifications in social work, counselling, human resource management and teaching or go on to take further qualifications at postgraduate level.

column2: SQA HigherBBC including English or another literate subject, eg. History, Geography, Modern Studies, Psychology.
GCE A LevelCC including a English or another literate subject, eg. History, Geography, Modern Studies, Psychology
Irish Leaving (H)BBCC at Honours level including English
Advanced GNVQAdvanced GNVQ in Health & Social Care at Merit level.
Second Year EntryHND Social Sciences
Minimum EntryFor further advice on minimum qualifications please use our Got a Question section.

MatureIn order to determine an applicant's ability to benefit from study or research at the University of Abertay Dundee, a range of standard and flexible criteria will be used in considering applications.



In most circumstances applications will be considered in light of the following:



Applications from mature students are assessed on the same criteria used for school leavers e.g. SQA Highers or GCE A Levels, where relevant school leaving qualifications exist. For those without standard entry qualifications, consideration is given to experience gained as well as professional qualifications and other forms of learning that could provide evidence of ability to benefit from a particular course.



The successful completion of approved access courses (such as those offered by Dundee College in association with the universities of Abertay, Dundee and St Andrews) provides significant evidence of ability to benefit from study at Abertay.



For further advice please use our Got a Question section.

OverseasThe University makes offers of entry to courses based on qualifications offered worldwide. For undergraduate level entry, if you are studying the International Baccalaureate, you would be expected to achieve at least 26 points. We consider a variety of alternative qualifications on an individual basis. Examples of the qualifications accepted for entry from Overseas students in recent years include: Chinese High School Diploma, Malaysia Advanced Certificate of Education (STPM), European Baccalaureate, West African Senior Secondary School Certificate (WASSCE) with a minimum of 5 passes at B3 or better from external examination plus an accceptable level of pass in JAMB, Indian Secondary Certificate plus Indian Higher Secondary Certificate (10+2), Pakistan Secondary Certificate plus Pakistan Higher Secondary Certificate, Hong Kong Advanced Level Certificate (HKALE).

All applicants are required to provide certified proof of competence in English Language. The University's minimum requirements are IELTS 6.0 (with no band lower than 5.0), TOEFL CBT 223, TOEFL 563, TOEFL IBT 85 or a suitable equivalent qualification.

column4:
Transferable skills

While studying on this course you will gain a number of practical skills that are useful in any field of business, such as how to use email, type reports, build a database and use the internet effectively, as well as being introduced to specialised software relevant to your subject choices. You will also learn how to sift through vast quantities of detailed information quickly, and to present the important points in a concise and straightforward manner. As you progress through the degree course you will gain other incidental skills which will prove invaluable in any future working environment. These may include:
1. Learning how to learn effectively
2. Self-motivation
3. Assertiveness
4. Time management
5. Meeting deadlines
6. Problem solving
7. Analysis, synthesis, discrimination and judgement
8. Logical and reasoned thinking.

Teamwork

Being able to work as a member of a team is an important quality in a University student. Working in a team situation allows you to utilise your own personal strengths and to build upon areas where you are lacking by learning from other people. It also allows you to gain experience in leading discussions and delegating responsibility, as well as learning to become an effective listener Â¡V an important leadership quality which can sometimes be overlooked. Making a positive contribution to a joint project allows you to develop team-working skills.
Working together on coursework often allows you to form close friendships in your social life as you learn to listen to and trust other peopleÂ¡Â¦s judgements.
